RECORD.TITLE: Le Pas d'acier
RECORD.NOTES: See Lesley- Anne Sayers' entry in "Filemaker". E-mail from Lesley-Anne Sayers on 7/01/2000: She mentions the 1931 and 1948 production of Le Pas d'Acier. " I am hoping the Met archives in New York will have substantial material on the 1931 production, and am waiting to hear from them. I know there is a film of the 1948 version but I have not yet been able to locate a copy." From Gorchakov p. 300-301: "[..] au mois de mai 1927, lorsque commencèrent les répétitions du 'Pas d'Acier', Diaghilev exigea un entracte entre les deux tableaux. Prokofiev orchestra rapidement un des numéros de son ballet 'Trapèze' conçu primitivement pour un petit orchestre de chambre resté inutilisé (Il entra plus tard comme 1er mouvement du Divertimento Op. 43). Gorchakov p.321-322: "Prokofiev et sa famille passèrent l'été à Culoz, dans le chateau moyenâgeux de la Fléchère. Là il décida de liquider quelques dettes envers des anciens matériaux musicaux. Il est question du 'Divertimento' op. 43 et de la troisième version de la 'Sinfonietta'. Le Divertimento naquit en quatre numéros, écrits à des époques différentes. Le premier et le troisième étaient composés encore en 1925, à la demande des 'Ballets Ambulants' de Romanoff qui, montant 'Trapèze', voulut y ajouter deux numéros supplémentaires. C'est pourquoi ces deux numéros avaient été conçus primitivement pour quintette, mais ne rentrèrent pas dans le Quintette op. 30. Le premier numéro eut un grand succès et Diaghilev l'inclut comme danse intermédiaire entre les deux tableaux du 'Pas d'Acier'. Le Larghetto fut ébauché en 1928 et le quatrième numéro sortit de la musique destinée à l'Enfant Prodigue et restée inutilisée. Prokofieff mit en ordre tous ces matériaux et les orchestra." See letter to Diaghilev: VIII/307/11.08.1925 [Ursinol]: letter also at Bibliotheque de l'opera/Garnier/Paris: Fonds Kochno. Letter from Yakulov: IX/172/12.10.+1925 Re titles, see Derzhanovsky: IX/269/11.11.1925 Archive (full score and piano reduction & recording) BH

RECORD.TITLE: Cinderella
RECORD.CUSTOM2: RGALI/1929/Op.1/067-071; RGALI/1929/Op.2/034 Russian National Library (St Petersburg)/Prokofiev/007-012
RECORD.NOTES: Archive (full score and vocal score & recording) BH* The English National Ballet production won the 1997 Lawrence Olivier Award for Best Dance Production and the 1996 Evening Standard award for Outstanding Production. The current run opened in Southampton (23.10.01) and is on tour to Oxford, Manchester, Bristol, Liverpool and ends at London Coliseum 11-19.1.02 (from email by Jacky - 19.11.2001). See Peter Bourne <pabalex@blueyonder.co.uk> 13 June 2003: about Ashton's production:"In my opinion, this perfectly interprets the ironic intent of the composer while enhancing the sense of mystery and magic in the music. However, it has one serious flaw. By totally excising the first part of Act 3 (the Prince's world journey), it fatally unbalances the clever structure of the whole, the last act being a merely a coda to Act 2. As a consequence it becomes a brief non entity." For list of numbers, see: \\ARIES\Q-DRIVE\prokofiev\word\FIONA\Cinderella_numbers.doc

RECORD.TITLE: Sonata for Two Violins
RECORD.NOTES: Archive (score & recording) BH. H. Robinson: composed 1932. (p.262, written for the Triton concert society in Paris. Composed in "Les Pins-Parasols" at Ste Maxime, on holiday in August 1932) Check with correspondence. Gorchakov, p.349:"La premiere audition de cette Sonate eut lieu a Moscou le 27 novembre 1932, interpretee par les violonistes D. Tzyganoff et B. Chririnsky. La premier parisienne eut lieu pour l'inauguration du "Triton", le 16 decembre de la meme annee, le jour meme de la premiere du ballet "Sur le Borysthene". Mais le ballet commencait une demi-heure plus tard et, apres la Sonate, toute une bande de musiciens, de critiques et, avec eux, l'auteur, se precipiterent du concert au Grand Opera" See letters to & from Robert Soetens XXXIII/54-55; 90, 98,109; 204; 210 Inaugural Concert of Triton: Date: 16 December 1932; Venue: Ecole Normale de musique; Programme: 3rd String Quartet - Laszlo Lajtha (première), Sonata for 2 Violins - Prokofiev (première), L'Horizon chimérique - Fauré, Sonatine for Violin and 'Cello - Honegger (première), String Quartet, Op. 45 - Roussel (première)

RECORD.TITLE: Love for Three Oranges
RECORD.NOTES: In XIV/301/13.04.1927: "The State Opera of Leningrad announces its arrival in Paris in June, specially to give 8 performances of "The Love to the Three Oranges" at the Grand Opera." [NM to check if it took place] In correspondence: (XXIV/88): "Notice: cet opéra fut commandé à M. Prokofieff peu de temps après son arrivée en Amérique, c'est-à-dire vers la fin de 1918. Le livret et la partition furent terminés par lui en septembre 1919 et la première repésentation eut lieu en décembre 1921, sous sa direction, à l'Opéra de Chicago. Cet opéra, en quatre actes et dix tableaux, avec un prologue, fut chanté en français, grâce à Mme Vera Janacopulos, qui voulut bien le traduire.) The Love for Three Oranges is being performed at NYC opera in the fall for only 5 performances (oct 17th - nov 5th 2000). in the Maurice Sendak version. See fight with Rouché re Paris performance: XXX/192-95/22.06.1932 Archive (full score and reduction & recording) BH

RECORD.TITLE: Egyptian Nights
RECORD.NOTES: Incidental music: Stage production by Alexandre Iakovlevich Tairov [1885-1950] for the Moscow Chamber (Kamerny) Theatre. Documents: Letter Prokofiev to Miaskovsky, 23 Dec 1933, 5 rue Valentin Haüy, Paris. [Perepiska: No. 368, pp 407/08 " I'm progressing with the music for the Tairov production; in no way can I make myself churn out this music as a run of the mill exercise, on the spur of the moment, and I am therefore spending lots of time on it." Letter Prokofiev to Miaskovsky, 2 January 1934, 5 rue Valentin Haüy, Paris. [Perepiska: No. 372, pp 412/13]. "I've just finished the music for Tairov's Egyptian Nights. [..] In ten days, I shall send it to Tairov." Letter Prokofiev to Gottlieb, 26 July 1934, 5 rue Valentin Haüy, Paris. [Archive: XXXVII/248] "I also have written the music for the 'Egyptian Nights', a new theatrical production which will have its première in November next at the Kamerny Theatre of Taïroff, Moscow. I have given a detailed interview on this production in the special theatre number of the 'Soviet Travel', 1934, N.3. [....] Moreover I have arranged symphonic suites of my ballet 'Sur le Borysthène', given in 1933 at the Grand Opéra, Paris, as well as of Egyptian Nights and of Lieutenant Kijé.' First Edition: xxxxx? Description: 44 scenes, with 30 musical numbers, some repeated -partly of fully- to make up the 44 numbers. Rhythmical declamation, some over the music, some alone in Nos. 17, 19, 37, 42, 43 & 44 No. 18: bass solo and male chorus No. 26: Tenor solo humming Suite for Symphonic Orchestra Op. 61 Commissioned by Moscow radio, as well as Lieutenant Kijé Suite. [See letter Prokofiev to Miaskovsky: Perepiska, 8 octobre 1934, 5 rue Valentin Haüy, Paris. No. 390, p. 430; "But you see, I did both suites - Kizhe and Egyptian - on a commission from the Radio"] Completion in September 1934: See Ms record 45/film R8824: end dated: 14/09/34 See letter to Miaskovsky, Perepiska: 17 September 1934, St Maxime: "I have just completed the Suite from Egyptian Nights". Performances: 1.Moscow Radio: 21 December 1934. Orchestra: xxxxx?, conducted by Prokofiev 2.Paris: 9 February 1936. Source: Le Guide du Concert, Février 1936. Column: à travers la critique. "Sur Nuits d'Egypte de M. Prokofieff " (1ere aud. Pasdeloup, le 9 fév.). [I presume that Prokofiev conducted]: review P. Blois: "....l'auditoire, silencieux depuis le début, acclama l'auteur qui eut la regrettable pudeur de ne pas bisser ce tableau" [To be checked] 3. Moscow, 22 December 1938: an all Prokofiev concert conducted by the composer. Programme: Egyptian Nights, Violin concerto No. 2 and Scythian Suite. [from Miaskovsky diary, Lamm: p. 271]. Place: xxxx? Orchestra xxxxxx? First Edition: Gutheil, 1934, Full score [Wrong date in commentary for 1ere of the play] Description: Seven parts No. 1: from No. 1 incidental music No. 2: from No. 6 incidental music No. 3: from No. 2 incidental music No. 4: from No. 11 incidental music, and other unidentified material as from RN 18 [To check] No. 5 from No. 19 incidental music No. 6 from parts of No. 19 incidental music and other unidentified material [To check] No. 7 from No. 27 & 28 incidental music Archive (full score with piano reduction)

RECORD.TITLE: Four Marches
RECORD.PUBLISHER: No.1: Marsh dlia Spartakiady/ dlia dukhovogo orkestra/partitura/Muzgiz 1937
RECORD.SECTION: No. 1: Marsh dlia Spartakiady[ in Bb M.]. No. 2: Pokhodnyi Marsh (Liricheskii) [in F M.] as in Muzyka 1968. No. 3: Pokhodnyi marsh (F dur) i No. 4: Kavalerivskii marsh (s khorom 'Cherez mostik')
RECORD.NOTES: The Shlifshtein catalogue, lists 4 marches: No 1:'Marsh dlia Spartakiady' , No. 2: 'Liricheskii marsh' . No. 3 'Pokhodnyi marsh'. No. 4: 'Kavaleriskii Marsh s khorom: 'Cherez Mostik'. But in the 'Muzyka' publication of 1968 which is: 'Pokhodnyi marsh' (Liricheskii). So, did Op. 69 consist of 3 marches or 4? I tend to go for the latter, ie 3 marches only because the recording of Op. 69 on the melodiia catalogue mentions only 3 marches. According to information gathered at the Library of the Association of Soviet Composers (Marina Petrovna Saveleva), Derzhanovsky orchestrated the first march for symphonic orchestra. Published in 1938, Muzgiz, SSK. The 1968 Muzyka edition consists of the following: pp. 2-21: Prokofiev's score of Pokhodnyi Marsh, (Liricheskii) pp. 22- 42: same work reorchestrated by V. Shpirko (I don't know who he was) pp. 43 to the end: the 3rd March which is recorded on the Melodiia LP, but with the same Shpirko's orchestration and edition. He says in the footnote p. 43 that this march had been written for a competition organised by the publishers Muzgiz in 1937. He also says that he has cut out a Trio from the original work because it was too difficult to perform. It remains to work out whether this last one is the one that Shlifshtein refers to as: Kavaleriskii Marsh (with the chorus: Cherez Mostik) See Vladimir Blok - 'Metod Tborcheskoi Raboty S. Prokofeva' (Muzyka: 1978) Number 4 was never included in the original publication (NM) Archive (score and parts & incomplete recording) BH*

RECORD.TITLE: Divertimento [for orchestra]
RECORD.NOTES: From Gorchakov p. 300-301: "Au mois de mai 1927, lorsque commencèrent les répétitions du 'Pas d'Acier', Diaghileff exigea un entracte entre les deux tableaux. Prokofiev orchestra rapidement un des numéros de son ballet 'Trapèze' conçu primitivement pour un petit orchestre de chambre et resté inutilisé (Il entra plus tard comme premier mouvement du 'Divertimento' Op. 43). Gorchakov p.321-322: "Prokofiev et sa famille passèrent l'été 1929 à Culoz, dans le chateau moyenâgeux de la Fléchère. Là il décida de liquider quelques dettes envers des anciens matériaux musicaux. Il est question du 'Divertimento' op. 43 et de la troisième version de la Sinfonietta. Le 'Divertimento' naquit en quatre numéros, écrits à des époques différentes. Le premier et le troisième étaient composés encore en 1925, à la demande des 'Ballets Ambulants' de Romanoff qui, montant 'Trapèze', voulut y ajouter deux numéros supplémentaires. C'est pourqoi ces deux numéros avaient été conçus primitivement pour quintette, mais ne rentrèrent pas dans le Quintette op. 39. Le premier numéro eut un grand succès et Diaghilev l'inclut comme danse intermédiaire entre les deux tableaux du 'Pas d'Acier'. Le Larghetto fut ébauché en 1928 et le quatrième numéro sortit de la musique destinée à 'l' Enfant Prodigue' et restée inutilisée. Prokofieff mit en ordre tous ces matériaux et les orchestra." Archive (score & recording) BH

RECORD.TITLE: Sinfonietta
RECORD.SECTION: 5 movts: Allegro Giocoso. Andante. Intermezzo: Vivace. Scherzo: Allegro risoluto. Final: Allegro Giocoso
RECORD.CUSTOM2: Piano reduction (dated 1909/1929; record 76) film 24717. Sotheby's RGALI/1929/Op.1/114; RGALI/1929/Op.2/041 See also RGALI catalogue f.1929, Op.1, pg.191-2, no.2
RECORD.NOTES: In a letter to Miaskovsky: Sontsovka 25 March (7 April) 1909, he says that he is starting to gather material for the Sinfonietta. He resumes the composition in Sontsovka in May. 3 of the 5 parts were given the names of characters from Wagner's operas.(see p.586). Kankarovich Anatolii Isaakovich proposed to perform it in Voronezh. SP had just heard R-K's Sinfonietta Op. 31 and was inspired by the genre. "Therefore I decided on the form of the sinfonietta and threw myself passionately into work: it was the first occurence in my life, when someone promised that an orchestra would perform from the manuscript the minute it was written. Till then, performance floated somewhere in between opportunity and intention.". Project fell through. (see letter Kankarovich p. 588/9). He revised it while in London in 1914 (see Sergei Prokofiev 1953-1963; Stat'i i Materialy. Sovetskii Kompozitor, M. 1962 p.265; note 57. Also correspondence with Ziloti re Sinfonietta and Scythian Suite. pp.256/7/8/9). Ziloti sponsored the Sinfonietta in 1915 Gorchakov p.321-322: "Prokofiev et sa famille passèrent l'été (1929) à Culoz, dans le chateau moyenâgeux de la Fléchère. Là il décida de liquider quelques dettes envers des anciens matériaux musicaux. Il est question du 'Divertimento' op. 43 et de la troisième version de la 'Sinfonietta' Prokofiev in Autobiography [Shlifshtein; p.76]. "I was not satisfied with the 1914 version of the Sinfonietta and so I took it part and put it together again, rewriting some sections but adding no new material. Incidentally the Sinfonietta has been comparatively rarely performed whereas * In Perepiska, note 3 for letter 176, p.507, the commentary mentions that the whereabouts of the piano arrangement for 4 hands are unknown. Archive (score of final version & recording) BH

RECORD.TITLE: Betrothal in a Monastery
RECORD.NOTES: Unconfirmed Notes relating to programme for sale on ebay (19.04.2007): "Program for a concert titled "Theatre Music of Two Lands," sponsored by the American-Soviet Music Society, City Center, New York City, May 12 [1947]. Four pages, 7 x 10 in., light horizontal creases and mild handling wear, otherwise clean and fine. A scarce survival from an interesting and eclectic presentation, supervised by composer Marc Blitzstein, dating to the brief postwar period before U.S. - Soviet tensions evolved into full-fledge Cold War. Among the composers represented were Leo Smit (who also performed at the keyboard), Aram Khachaturian (an excerpt from his little-known film score Girl 217), Sergei Prokofiev (including the American premiere of his Betrothal in a Convent and the world premiere of his ballet Summer Day), Louis Gruenberg, Lev Schwartz, and Gail Kubik (the world premiere of his A Mirror for the Sky; Kubik would go on to win the Pulizter Prize in Music in the following decade)."

RECORD.TYPE_OF_WORK: [World premiére] First perf in Russia? Had already been performed in Boston, see 1927 diary, 6 March.
RECORD.NOTES: "After the violin pieces came the Quintet, and here the Moscow musicians surpassed themselves, playing with unexpected brilliance and enthusiasm. The piece sounded excellent. Of course in time it will be played even better but even so this performance is far superior to the one in Boston when Koussevitzky said to me, 'My dear, this thing doesn't "sound" at all.' (March 1927, Soviet Diary 1927)
